name: asparagus-officinalis
definition: Asparagus is a perennial flowering plant species in the genus Asparagus.
description:
Asparagus is an herbaceous perennial plant grown for its young shoots, or spears, which are eaten as a vegetable.

The asparagus plant is tall with scale like leaves emerging from the underground stem (rhizome) and has stout stems and feathery foliage.

The flowers are bell shaped and occur alone or in pairs.

They are green-white to yellow in color.

After flowering, a round red berry is formed with 1 to 6 black seeds.

Asparagus can live for 20 or more years and can attain a height between 100 and 150 centimeters.

Asparagus spears can be eaten raw or cooked.

They are low in calories and very low in sodium.

Asparagus is a particularly good source of vitamins B6, A, C, E and K, thiamin, riboflavin, folic acid, dietary fiber, and protein.

It also contains plenty of minerals: calcium, magnesium , zinc, iron, phosphorus, potassium, copper, and others.

Its young shoots are used as a spring vegetable.

Asparagus is sometimes used to help with weight loss and to reduce high blood pressure.

Other uses include treatment of joint pain, hormone imbalances in women, dryness in the lungs and throat, constipation, nerve pain.

Asparagus grows in a temperate climate.

It grows best in regions with hot days and cool nights and requires 90 to 150 days of cold temperature to break dormancy.

The best soil types for asparagus are deep, loose, light clays, with much organic matter, and light sandy loams.

Asparagus should be planted in a sunny location in the home garden.

It is best to avoid low lying areas as a late frost will cause damage to newly emerged spears.

Growing asparagus from seed is more time consuming and labor intensive than growing from divided crowns.

Asparagus spears are ready to harvest when they reach 17 to 22 centimeters in length.

They can simply be snapped by hand close to the ground.

Majority of globally consumed asparagus originate from China that produces nearly 7 million tons of this vegetable each year.

Sources differ as to the native range of asparagus, but generally include most of Europe, northern Africa and western temperate Asia.

Asparagus history goes back as far as that of the leek and has been consumed for over 2000 years.

contextual.caption:
Garden asparagus is cultivated in most temperate and subtropical parts of the world.

It will thrive in soils too salty for other crops, but acidic soils are to be avoided.

featured.caption:
Asparagus flowers are bell shaped and green-white to yellow in color.

They occur alone or in clusters composed of two to three flowers.

facts.name: Rich source of nutrients
facts.value: Asparagus is rich source of dietary fibers, vitamins C, B2, B9, K and E and minerals such as iron, manganese, phosphorus and potassium.

facts.name: Produce bell-shaped flowers
facts.value: Unharvested spears produce bell-shaped, greenish-white or yellow flowers. Asparagus is dioecious plant, which means that male and female flowers develop on the separate plants. Flowers grow individually or in clusters composed of two to three flowers.

facts.name: Romans preserved asparagus on Alps
facts.value: Fastest Roman athletes were carrying asparagus toward the Alps (to preserve it in the cold temperatures) while another, "asparagus fleet", was responsible to bring best-quality asparagus to Rome.

facts.name: Has underground stem
facts.value: Asparagus has underground stem (rhizome) and strong, fibrous root system. At the beginning of the spring, rhizome starts to produce buds that transform into spears - edible parts of asparagus.

facts.name: Aphrodisiac properties
facts.value: Asparagus has aphrodisiac properties due to high level of vitamin E which is essential for the synthesis of sex hormones.

facts.name: Asparagus has fern-like leaves
facts.value: Asparagus has multi-branched, feathery, fern-like leaves.

facts.name: Favorite food of King Louis XIV
facts.value: Asparagus was the favorite type of food of King Louis XIV. Frenchmen started to cultivate asparagus in the greenhouse to ensure year-round stashes of this vegetable.

facts.name: Popular in the ancient Egypt
facts.value: Asparagus was very popular in the ancient Egypt. Bunch of asparagus can be seen on the walls of many tombs.

facts.name: Spears can be green, white or purple
facts.value: Spears can be green, white or purple. White spears grow below the ground, without exposure to the sunlight (which is essential for the activation of pigments in the plant). Purple variety is artificially created (genetically altered asparagus), but it changes the color into green during the cooking.

facts.name: Was used as laxative
facts.value: Asparagus was used as laxative and in treatment of toothache and poor eyesight in the past. It contains substances that can alleviate symptoms of the migraine, PMS and hangover.

facts.name: Can grow 15 centimeters per day
facts.value: Spears can grow 6 inches per day during a period of 6 to 7 weeks. Harvest of the fully grown spears takes place each day or every 4 to 5 days, depending on the outer temperatures (higher temperature accelerates growth).

facts.name: Asparagus fruits are poisonous
facts.value: Fruit of asparagus is small red berry. Unlike spears, berry is poisonous for humans.

facts.name: Spears are the edible part
facts.value: After removal of the woody end of asparagus, spears can be boiled, microwaved, cooked, fried, marinated or pickled.

facts.name: Asparagus is perennial plant
facts.value: Asparagus is perennial plant. First harvest takes place 3 years after planting. Asparagus produces spears until the age of 15 to 20 years.

facts.name: Ca reach 1.5 meters in height
facts.value: Asparagus has stout stem that can reach 100 to 150 centimeters in height.
